My First Steps

By Michael • August 20, 2020
⚲ El Paso, TX
Scroll to Bottom

DXC Technology

Fresh from graduating from the University of Texas at El Paso, I found the first stepping stone of my career locally at HP, the hardware and software service enterprise. I still remember the offer letter, the thrill of being selected and the anxiety of telling myself that I pale in comparison to the developers I would be surrounded by. Fortunately for me, as soon as I entered the training room, I immediately recognized a couple of friendly faces from my college courses. El Paso really is the smallest big town and at this moment, I knew I was in the right place. The butterflies evaporated and I was ready for whatever the future held for me.

My days at HP weren’t without their share of drastic changes. “HP” quickly become “Hewlett Packard Enterprise”, clarifying that we were the software side of the company while the former was responsible for hardware. Then perhaps a year later, the company became DXC Technology the name HP or Hewlett-Packard became an entirely separate entity.

While supporting DXC Technology, I provided support as the administrator of the Project and Portfolio Management Center (PPM) application used by our client, the Division of Health Care Financing and Policy (DHCFP) located in the state of Nevada. My team focused on delivering efficient solutions in order to streamline our customer’s daily workflow.

During my tenure, I would say my primary growth was in following the full software development lifecycle from beginning to end. As my role became more abstract in nature, I found myself responsible for all parts of the lifecycle. I would identify requirements by initiating meetings with our customer and then writing a full Statement of Work document to encapsulate all of their essential functionalities. These meetings were extremely common and guaranteed to be frequent as requirements naturally evolved and priorities shifted. Being a one man developer, I designed solutions, developed workflows in a debugging environment, managed our relational databases, scheduled releases, wrote, conducted and documented quality assurance test cases/results before deploying projects into our production environment (and next came post production testing!).

Unfortunately, extended leave was not an option to me, so I made the extremely difficult decision to accept the offer of a lifetime even though it meant being unable to return to my position at DXC. Although almost my entire team supporting the Nevada account were located at other DXC locations across the nation, I felt greatly appreciated and accomplished by the end of my employment. I was someone who walked in with a plethora of self-doubt and no clue how the application worked and left as the PPM expert and a highly valued team member. I would miss the warm “good morning” exchanged with Joyce daily, the occasional team doughnuts and playing Super Smash Bros. for 3DS with my incredibly good friends, Danny and Miguel during lunch and break times. It warmed my heart on my final day, to be given a cake that read “Michael, good luck in California!” I couldn’t believe it, I was headed to work for my favorite media website IGN Entertainment.
